title: Mining industry proposes cutting unions out of negotiations
text:
The Minerals Council of Australia says greater competition between parties seeking to act for workers in workplace negotiations would be good for employees and the country. by Joanna Mather Employees can benefit if the privileged role of unions is watered down in industrial relations law, the lobby group for minerals companies says.
The group, which represents one of the most unionised industries, wants awards replaced with a safety net system of minimum standards, without a special role for unions.
A policy paper commissioned by the Minerals Council of Australia as part of debate about workplace reform says greater competition between parties seeking to act for workers in workplace negotiations would be good for employees and the country.
This is because unions negotiate agreements for 400,000 people who are not members but have no one else to bargain for them.
"There is evidence that greater competition in the provision of collective bargaining services would enhance the performance of Australia's labour market," the paper says.
"Better outcomes can be achieved by reducing entrenchment of insiders and ensuring that union officials feel the heat from their members and are incentivised to serve the interests of those members."
Replacing awards with a "safety net system of minimum standards, without a special role for unions, would be one of the ways to achieve more competition".
Another option is to "remove special union rights and preferences in a bargaining context, with equal footing given to alternative bargaining agents". Removal of "entrenched union rights in relation to governance of superannuation funds" should also be considered, the paper says.
 "The view has tended to be ... that employees require the 'collective muscle' of trade unions for effective negotiation," the paper says.
"However, there is an equally valid concern that measures which on the face of it protect the collective muscle of workers simply serve to empower trade union officials at the expense of members' interests."
Australia could look to New Zealand, where changes in the 1990s put collective and individual bargaining on a similar footing, the paper says.
"Opening up trade unions to greater competition is not an anti-union measure. Rather, as New Zealand's experience following the introduction of the Employment Contracts Act in 1991 showed, removal of entrenched powers led to a market shakeout that ultimately benefited both workers and some trade unions," it says.
"Trade unions that proved to be effective bargaining agents, and that gained a reputation for helping employers to achieve productivity growth that was shared with their members, managed to grow their membership despite the underlying decline in unionisation."
